Posts.Title: Opinions Please KellyC saint

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2008 08:19PM KiminJax wrote: Hi Kelly,  I know it's a difficult decision to make and I can't help you with your decision.  I can share my experience though.  I was in a double blind avastin study called the "ribbon one" study.  Neither me or my doctor knew for sure whether I was on it.  However, I was told that if I had progression on the study and I was not getting the avastin before that I would be guaranteed to get it after progression.  I can't remember how long before we checked (3 months or 3 rounds?) but I did have progression and so then was put into the mode of being given it for sure and I hate to tell you this but I still had progression so then was taken off the study and given a whole new chemo.  Similar to the side effects above the blood pressure sky rocketed.  I didn't have any bloody nose but did need to be put on blood pressure medication.  During the first half of the study believe it or not I kept hoping my BP would go up because I knew that was a common side effect and I was really hoping I was getting the avastin.  We know that each woman is different so that is why we have the trials - to see what works with whom and what doesn't.  And, you do get all that special monitoring too - lots of scans.  The only thing my insurance paid for was the drug itself.  It did not pay for the scans and all the extra stuff that went along with it.  Good luck with your decision.  It's a personal choice that only you can make.  I would go on another study in a heartbeat because you never know when one of the studies will result in a cure.  I hope to be around to see it.
Posts.Title: Opinions Please KellyC saint

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2008 11:11PM KiminJax wrote: Kelly,  I'm so glad you are going on your trip with your husband.  If you can, try to put the cancer on a shelf and just have plain old fun.  To answer your question you need to understand what sweetmamma said above.  Avastin is not chemotherapy - it enhances chemotherapy.  So, I pulled out my old notes and in the initial phase I was doing Avastin with Abraxane and after the progression I was doing Avastin with Gemzar and Cisplatin.  So, you will be doing some type of chemo at the same time you are doing the Avastin. One more thing, I was going to Mayo Clinic (still am) and even though the Avastin had been approved by some sort of governing body I called and asked them to give me the Avastin off trial and they would not do it.  I felt so cornered and so angry.  They would not do it off trial - I had to go on the trial if I wanted to get it.  My understanding is that since that time the FDA has approved Avastin for breast cancer so it seems to me you should be able to get it off trial but I don't know.  Man that pissed me off though - I really felt angry (I guess I still am).  Anyway, best of luck to you as you make this decision.  You're the only one that can decide and whatever decision you make is the right one for you.  There are plenty of chemos out there and they'll be plenty of trials in the future (hopefully) if you decide not to do it now.  Good luck and don't let anyone judge whatever decision you make.  It will be the right one for you.  Kim
Posts.Title: Opinions Please KellyC saint

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 08:52AM KiminJax wrote: Fitz, Maria, all, I share your anger.  I'm going on two solid years of chemo since getting my mets (anniversary on 9/6).  I've been through a long list of chemos that don't work very long before progression.  For two years I put on the "mask" and did the "aren't I remarkable" thing and really gave everyone the false impression that I'm doing just fine.  BTW, my daughter told me once that when the response is "oh I'm fine" that "fine" means f-ed up, insane, neurotic, and emotional. I too am going through a period where I'm pissed as hell at this disease.  I'm angry about the chemo, the pills, the s/e's, people that call me on the phone to check on me (rather than do something with me), a husband that doesn't know what to do with me.  I just found out last week that my insurance company, Aetna, has terminated their relationship with Mayo Clinic where I have been going for two years and now I have to find a new oncologist, new facility, everything.   I'm pretty sure my onc told me that the Navelbine I'm on now is my last chemotherapy available outside of clinical trial drugs.  I felt pretty secure at Mayo being leading edge with trials - now I have to find some place completely new.  I'm angry about it all.  We have a right to bitch.  I don't know if we go through seasons where we feel down when we're going through this but we have a right to feel our feelings.  God bless each and every one of us for our endurance.  I think it's okay if once in a while we lose our patience and bitch, cry, moan, rant, scream, and stomp our feet.  It ain't fair.  Kim

Posts.Content: KiminJax wrote: Hi Everyone,  I just want to share. I am so proud of my 25 (just 25) year old daughter.  The backstory is that I was dx'ed at 47 with the garden variety stage II BC.  My recurrance was in 2006.  In between I was tested for BRCA because my mom is an ovarian cancer survivor and her mother had breast cancer.  Low & behold I came back with the BRCAII mutation.  At first, my daughter didn't want to have anything to do with being tested.  But, when she saw her ob/gyn for an annual the gyn convinced her she really should.  She had the genetic counseling done first and prepared for her test.  Her test came back with the exact same mutation I have.  I explained to her how grateful I am that she has this data and can make choices about her lifestyle, monitoring, etc.  Had I know during my life, I may have made choices to prevent too.  Anyway, yesterday she had her first visit with the breast health clinic and they did a mamogram, and ultra sound.  The clinic will have her come back in six months for an MRI.  Then, her routine will be 6 mths mammy, 6 months later MRI.  Praise the Lord!  Early detection saves lives.  As for profolactic surgery, the doctor does not think it is necessary at this time.  After all, she wants to have babies one day and breast feed. Here's the rub.  The doctor is recommending she go on Tamoxifen for five years.  I know Tamoxifen through me into menopause.  The doctor told her that with young girls it will not do this, they will still have periods and when she is ready to have babies it will take about a year to get the Tami out of her body and then she can become pregnant.  Does anyone have experience with this on the boards?  Taking tami and then having babies?  Just curious. Mostly, I am just so proud of her to face the music at this early age.  But, if she can avoid going through what I've gone through it will be totally worth it.  Kim Dx'ed in September 2004, mets to lungs in September 2006, mets to brain in September 2008. Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2008 03:50AM KiminJax wrote: Hi vhgh,  I'm newly dx'ed with the brain mets (also have lung mets).  I had a seizure while driving and thank God I did not hurt anyone.  I'm going to finish WBR on October 1.  I think I will have completed 15 rounds.  I am a little concerned that you won't be able to accomplish all of your activities during this time.  My experience is that the radiation is very fatiguing.  I now enjoy sitting in my recliner with my eyes closed most of the time.  I'm not really sleeping but just sitting.  I trust that this will go away once done and I'll have a little energy back.  I do get dizzy and I choose to use a walker temporarily for my own safety.  I have been told I cannot drive until I have gone six months seizure free and I'm supposed to report this so the clock starts ticking to the DMV.  I've also been advised not to report it in case I feel I can drive sooner.  You will need help getting to your appointments for a little while for sure.  I used to be a driver for the ACS Road to Recovery program and I plan to call them once my routine daily visits end on 10/1.  My friends have been great but I can only go so long before feeling a little like a nuisance.  I agree with the others that it is a good time to reach out to neighbors, kids, and get the help you need with your animals.  I've never cared for large animals but this does sound challenging.  Even if someone is there with you to keep an eye on your balance, strenghth, etc.  Good luck and please keep us posted.  This brain stuff is new to me too and I'm still learning through my cyber sisters how to take the next steps.  Love to you,  Kim

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 04:09AM KiminJax wrote: I'm doing Navelbine and (I can't believe I'm saying this) it's my favorite chemo so far.  I've been on several.  It's quick and easy - less than one hour.  I get fluids for about 15 minutes, the Navelbine titrates for 10 minutes and then fluids for another few minutes.  I'm in and out of the chair in less than one hour.  My only side effect is a feeling of heartburn that goes away.  Oddly, I've had progression on Navelbine but he wants me to stay on it.  It is one of the few chemos that can get past the brain/blood barrier. I'm very interested in stem cell transplant.  Is that an option for any of us?  I know a lady who had a stem cell transplant 10 years ago.  She had mets to her liver.  She is still doing great and is cancer free.  I have no knowledge of this procedure though.  Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 04:57PM KiminJax wrote: Snooch, I applaud your wanting to get active even as a stage IV cancer patient in treatment.  It sounds like you have a lot going on physically that could cause the symptoms you're experiencing.  I just want to throw my 2 cents in and just suggest a lower aerobic routine.  For example, yoga is an excellent way to stay fit, balanced, toned and is in no way an easy workout but is effective without the same strain.  Walking is better on your knees than running.  Swimming is excellent and keeps you cool at the same time.  I really admire your desire.  I am an avid bicycle rider.  I used to run but just lost interest since my diagnosis.  Biking has filled the gap for me.  I take great pride in riding between 50 and 70 miles a week and undergoing treatment on a weekly basis.  I squeeze in yoga when I can just because I love it.  Whenever I finish I bike ride I'm hot, sweaty, a little fatigued (depending) and damn happy because I feel like I'm kicking cancer's butt.  I encourage anyone that is able to stay active doing something so that the cancer can't win.  At least not yet.  Love & Hugs,  Kim

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 10:27PM KiminJax wrote: Stephanie, I just read the most recent message above.  I know you are afraid.  Please please call your doctor and get seen.  Try to be assertive, I know they can be difficult sometimes but remember, the onc works for you.  I too feel full a lot but I assume it is related to the plethera of drugs I get on a weekly basis.  Stay on top of the diahrea meaning keep pushing the fluids so that you don't get dehydrated.  But please call as soon as you can and tell them you need to be seen ASAP to look at your immediate symptoms of fullness and diarhea.  Also, I hope I'm not overstepping my bounds but this disease can be very scary and depressing.  I personally take Effexor each day and Lorazepam as needed as an anti anxiety.  We are faithful women and I turn to the Lord for my strength and I try to give all this up to Him but He knows me and sometimes I just can't handle it all.  I figure the Lord put the brains into the scientists that have given us these medications to ease our minds and to calm our nerves.  He knows I love Him, I turn to Him, I pray to Him, and I worship Him and I am not ashamed to say I still need the Effexor and the Lorazepam to also get me through.  My point is, if you're not already on something you may want to ask about something like this to help you on your really bad days.  I love you and you are not alone and we'll pray you through this.  Kim

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 06:28AM KiminJax wrote: I'm surprised the onc is not having you do the neupogen.  When my white count is low, even though I can't have the chemo he still has me do the neupogen.  You may want to ask abou that.  I've had the TPA a couple of times and while it works,  it's annoying to spend the extra hour.  I have found a routine that will give a blood return everytime.  Before leaving for the onc's office I put a heating pad on the area.  Then, while I'm in the shower I keep a warm wet cloth on the port the whole time.  Then, on the ride to the onc's office I have a hand held vibrator (it's not what you think girls) called knuckles.  I massage the port and my neck on the way in.  I have not had a problem with my port returning blood since.  It's kind of a pain to go through all that but my chemo (Navelbine) is whats called a vesicant and if they don't get a blood return I don't get my chemo so it's important to me.  Again, wet heat, dry heat, and massage work ever time.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 05:37PM KiminJax wrote: Hi There - I am also ER+, PR- and HER2- like your mom.  I have lung mets.  I've tried many different chemos and am still looking for the right combo and I am expecting to be NED one of these days.  I agree with the other posters.  Be the good patient and follow what the onc tells you to do.  It is a matter of trying different combos to see what will work.  I've always been under the impression that hormonals are an option for me, especially if I need a chemo break.  Except for the tamoxifen I have not tried those yet because I want to be as aggressive as possible.  Thus far, the chemos aren't wearing me down.  I hope your mom might consider joining our group.  We are all survivors.  We have our good and bad days and are here for each other when needed.  Give her big hugs from us and let her know she is not alone.  It is scary at first but once you start learning all the survival stories out there, it can become very inspirational.  Good luck with your mom.  Kim

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2008 07:41PM KiminJax wrote: Hi Carrie - Lung mets here too.  I just celebrated two years of fighting the mets on September 6!  I've been through a lot of chemos and am now on Navelbine.  I'm kind of glad to hear you're' starting on it because for the first time in a long time something is working for me.  My lung tumors did shrink on the Navelbine.  I continue to take it.  The only side effect I've had is a little heart burn that lasts only a few hours.  Otherwise, it is the easiest chemo I have taken yet!  I could take it for years and years if it keeps working.  I go one a week, no breaks.  I do self-inject neupogen once a day for four days after the chemo.  One neulasa shot would do the same thing but I can't take the neulasta.  Occassionally I have arenesp too.  But really, it's been so easy for me.  I did the Avastin a while ago and it really spiked my blood pressure.  I'm glad to be off it.  God bless you and please know you are among friends here.  You are not alone.  Love and best wishes.  Kim
